'Cortisol', known more formally as 'hydrocortisone' (INN, USAN, BAN), is a
steroid hormone, more specifically a glucocorticoid, produced by the zona
fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. It is released in
response to stress and a low level of blood glucocorticoids. Its primary
functions are to increase blood sugar through gluconeogenesis; suppress the
immune system; and aid in fat, protein and carbohydrate metabolism. It also decreases bone formation. Various synthetic forms
of cortisol are used to treat a variety of diseases.
